title.narrative: Strengthening agribusiness relations for sustainable profits of producer associations in the Cauca Region

description.narrative: The training will contribute to strengthening the capacities of CREPIC and its local partners to provide specialized knowledge and coaching to agricultural commodity chains with the aim of creating value for the market and long-term sustainability of the sector. The focus of the training is on strengthening producer associations and their business relationships, access to markets, marketing and the generation of added value in the products.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Inception w/shop: Understanding partners
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative: Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period. + In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
The TMT was embedded in the capacity building component of the CLED project (OKP-COL-10009) and focused on improving the requesting organisation's (CREPIC) and partners' capacity to strengthen the business performance of farming associations in the selected value chains, many of which are made up by women, indigenous people and demobilised FARC members.
As indicated earlier, the initial TMT programme included field work to apply the acquired knowledge and skills in the field, coached by iCRA. Due to COVID 19, field work could not be conducted, and trainees did not have the opportunity to interact with the above mentioned actors in value chains as initially intended; and could therefore only exhibit improved analytical and functional skills in the case study used online. Therefore, we judge that we were only partially successful in reaching the desired objectives.
Even if the COVID 19 pandemic forced us to extend the TMT and postpone training activities several times, the interest of staff from the different organizations in following the TMT remained high. We designed an online training programme that kept interaction between participants lively.
We submitted a new TMT (20 January 2021), that include now three more co-requesting organisations who had sent staff to this TMT and if granted, our aim is to continue the engagement and learning started with this TMT.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
- Output 1. CREPIC, SENA, ESAP, FUP staff have improved knowledge and skills in analysing agro-enterprise competitiveness and value chain improvement strategies. Achievement: 23 participants (including stakeholders beyond CREPIC, SENA, ESAP and FUP – see list of participants) analysed the coffee value chain (own selected case study) and made suggestion on how to improve the chain.
- Output 2. CREPIC, SENA, ESAP, FUP staff have improved knowledge and skills in facilitating multi-stakeholder processes. Achievement: Already the first workshop, still residential (before COVID 19), was joined by participants from more organisations than initially envisaged and allowed practising multi-stakeholder engagement in-situ. Even the postponement of activities due to COVID 19 did not affect this, in fact, even more stakeholders joined the online sessions, and in breakout online rooms we could continue working with different stakeholder groups.
- Output 3. CREPIC, SENA, ESAP, FUP staff have improved knowledge and skills in linking small-scale producers to agricultural markets. Achievement: The initial field work embedded in the training was designed to engage with small-scale producers. This was not possible due to COVID 19 and we could only discuss options in the online sessions but not test in real-life context, thus we judge this output as only partially achieved.
-Output 4. REPIC, SENA, ESAP, FUP staff have improved knowledge and skills in gender equity and empowering women within value chains.Achievement: iCRA based its training on the CASE approach, whose key values or principles are ownership, empowerment and sustainability. Initially, as in output 3, we had planned to engage with female small-scale producers, unfortunately this component had to remain at a conceptual level, thus we also judge this output as only partially achieved.
​

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 09-03-2021: Non governmental organisations (Foundations, Associations, Committees) were counted under the private organisations.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 09-03-2021: The initial field work embedded in the training was designed to engage with small-scale producers (application of acquired knowledge and skills). This was not possible due to COVID 19 and we could only discuss options in the online sessions but not test in real-life context (working environment).

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication
B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: 56% of the participants were women. Each participating institution was at least represented by one woman and interestingly enough, the representative of the Foundation Women's World was a man. More and more women in Colombia are very qualified and joining institutions. The Colombian requesting organisation (Regional Centre for Productivity and Innovation of Cauca) is led by a woman and the institution has more professional women than men.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
Participants acknowledged:
- Participatory knowledge building
- Teamwork and articulation
- Jointly building knowledge and skills
- Development based on creativity
- Knowledge and strategies to share in the territory
- Unifying vision among actors
- Recognizing themselves as equals, as part of a constructive learning process.
​
